newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.KOREA LIMITS BUSINESSES OF SOME LIFE-INSURERS.
newsitem.headline: S.KOREA LIMITS BUSINESSES OF SOME LIFE-INSURERS.

text.p: South Korea's finance ministry said on Saturday it had decided to limit some business activities of five life insurance companies because of insufficient capital to cover policies.
A ministry statement said the five were unlisted Dong Ah, Handuk, Hankuk, Kukmin and Daeshin Life Insurance.
The government banned the five companies from issuing retirement pension insurance policies for 1998 and cut their sales of floating rate insurance products by 10 percent.
About 33 life insurers are operating in South Korea, the world's sixth biggest life insurance market.

Analysts warned many of them were technically insolvent. Concerns over the solvency of South Korean life insurers have been raised in the wake of the 200 billion yen ($1.58 billion) failure in April of Japan's Nissan Mutual Life.
South Korea set the solvency margin requirement for life insurers at one percent over policy reserves, compared with four percent in the U.K.

As 18 life insurers, including the five companies, had a policy reserve shortage totalling 1.44 trillion won at the end of fiscal 1996, ending March, the government ordered them to raise their capital by March, 1997, the statement said.
But just one life insurer met the government requirement and the remaining 17 were ordered to fulfil their obligation by March, 1998.
The statement said the capital shortage in the five insurers ranged between 50 billion and 100 billion won.
